definitions.definition: with no or very little light, especially because it is night

examples.text: a dark room/street/forest/night
What time does it **get dark** in summer?
Then the theatre **went dark**.
It was dark outside and I couldn't see much.
The sky was still dark.
Use lights to illuminate dark corners.
It gets dark at about six o'clock.
As it grew dark, they gathered round the fire.
It's only three o'clock and it's nearly dark already.
They stepped into the dark room and shone the torch.
He stumbled along through the dark forest.

definitions.definition: not light; closer in shade to black than to white

examples.text: dark blue/green/red/brown
Darker colours are more practical and don't show stains.

definitions.definition: having a colour that is close to black

examples.text: He wore a **dark suit** and a plain tie.
dark-coloured wood
The **dark clouds** in the sky meant that a storm was coming.
Sue has long dark hair.
He was handsome with dark eyes.
Even if you have dark skin, you still need protection from the sun.
a dark handsome stranger

definitions.definition: mysterious; hidden and not known about

examples.text: There are no **dark secrets** in our family.
There was a **darker side** to his nature.
the dark forces of the imagination
My mind was full of dark thoughts.

definitions.definition: unpleasant and without any hope that something good will happen

examples.text: the darkest days of Fascism
The film is a dark vision of the future.
The theatre stayed open even in the darkest days of the war.

definitions.definition: produced with the back part of the tongue close to the back of the mouth. In many accents of (= ways of pronouncing) English, dark /l/ is used after a vowel, as in ball.
a person who does not tell other people much about their life, and who surprises other people by having interesting qualities
a person taking part in a race, etc. who surprises everyone by winning
to keep something secret and not tell people about it

examples.text: He’s got two children? Well he’s kept that dark, hasn’t he!

wordOrigin: Old English deorc, of Germanic origin, probably distantly related to German tarnen ‘conceal’.
